PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions have not been answered by others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Don't hesitate to give details or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914 and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Generally it was considered a good move.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With family members traveled by train.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

From Ontario through to Chicago and then to North West to Manitoba there.

14. What incidents of the journey/meet do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

It was a long tedious journey and we were very anxious to get there.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At Bill Boyd's place at Hazel Vaughn.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

In Qu'Appelle, Saskatchewan.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Began farming in Qu'Appelle in 1892 and moved to the farm in 1902.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Running the store, grain elevator, and general farming.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
There was considerable excitement during the spring & summer of 1885 when the North West rebellion was at its height. Indian runners from Batoche, Daniel Albert came down contacting.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

There was considerable excitement during the spring & summer of 1885 when the North West rebellion was at its height. Indian reserves from Batoche and Prince Albert came down contacting the Indians on the Pine Hills and Crooked Lake reserves, urging them to join in a general uprising to exterminate the white settlers.

Those were anxious days especially among the wives mothers of the district. It was, however, soon apparent that the chiefs of both reserves were going to remain loyal.

Until well after the turn of the century that automobiles came into use.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Most of them thought it was a very wise move and suggested that they might follow in the near future.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? My father and a neighbor loaded a car with settlers' effects at Trenton Ont., about March 10th, 1884 and came West in an immigrant train. We crossed the St. Clair river at Sarnia Ont.

13. How long did your journey take? From there we traveled by C.P.R. arriving at Indian Head, Man., 21st

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? We stayed over night at Bill Pottle's Hotel, a good host and was ready for our trip out next day. The homestead was about four miles southeast of the present town of Abernethy. We crossed the Qu'Appelle river at Blackmore. Located in later years.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? See above, No. 15.

Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

My father had built a small log shack in the fall of 1883 which only accommodated a couple of beds and a very few pieces of furniture. All household effects including a year's supply of food and fuel had been stored in a big tent near the shack. He went to build a suitable log house after arriving. Within ten days however, calamity hit them. A fierce prairie fire swept through the area and destroyed everything. They had very little money and a job of any kind was extremely hard to find. This was a dreadful blow to the family and my aunt finished my poor mother. At that time all the government relief would have been a God-send.

It was my job during the summer of 1889 and 1890...
GARRATT, Mr. Alfred Webster

Milestone, Sask.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Most of them thought it was a very wise move and suggested that they might follow in the near future.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family), friends or other group?

My father and a neighbor loaded a car with settlers effects at Trenton Ont., about March 1864 and came West on an immigrant train. We crossed the St Clair river at Sarnia Ont., and then on our way through Chicago, Minneapolis, and on north through Emerson on to Winnipeg.

From there we travelled by C.P.R. arriving at Indian Head, May 21st.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

14. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

Writing by hand

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We stood over night at Bill Boyd's Hotel and got a good rest and was ready for our trip out toward their house which was about four miles both the east and west of present day Indian Head. Located on the south side of the road.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

See above, no. 15.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

My father had built a small log shack in the fall of 1883 which only accommodated a couple of beds and a very few pieces of furniture. It was a big tent near the shack. He used a hand saw and planned to build a suitable log house after seeding. But in the fall of 1884 he had to sell his land and move to another place. This was a great blow to the family and extremely hard to handle. My poor mother at that time slightest government relief would have been a God-send.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Most of them thought it was a very wise move and suggested that they might follow in the near future.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)? My father and a neighbor located at Emerson, with settlers' effects at Trenton Ont., about 60 miles west of Emerson, embarked on the train. We crossed the North Clair River at Barrie Ont., and continued south through Emerson on to Winnipeg. From there we travelled by C.P.R. arriving at Indian Head, Jan. 21st.

13. What route of transportation did you take? Through Emerson on to Winnipeg.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

15. How did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? Here did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? I stayed over night at Bill Boyce's Hotel. I got a good rest ready for our trip out toward the homestead which was ready for our trip out toward the homestead which was four miles south of the town of Aboretum. We passed the Quappelle River at Blackwood P.C.W. located 7 miles west of the town of Aboretum.

16. Did you settle or take up land? Yes, No?

17. Any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan?

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came? My father was a farmer and the children pitched in an odd job occasionally. In the summer getting berries or hops. After coming West I got a job herding cattle at the handsome wage of 40s per day (not per hour). This included milking and all the other chores I could do. This was my job during the summers of 1894 and 1895.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Most of them thought it was a very wise move and suggested that they might follow in the near future.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? My father and I traveled together with a group of seven people from Trenton, Ont., about 150 miles north along the St. Clair River to Sarnia, Ont.

13. How did you reach Winnipeg? We traveled north through Emerson on to Winnipeg via C.P.R. arriving at Indian Head, Sask., first.

16. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came? My father was a farmer and the children pitched in an odd job occasionally. In the summer picking berries or hops. After coming West got a job handling cattle at the handsome wage of $40 per day (not parlor). This included milking and all the other chores I could do. This was my job during the summers of 1908 and 1909.
